title: A man has to buy some oranges at the price of 12 and the same orange at the rate of Rs. 8. If he sells both oranges at a price of ₹ 10, then what is his percentage loss or profit? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let me think of the transaction this way. In transaction A he buys at Rs 12 each, sells at Rs 10 each and incurs a loss of 2 ÷ 12 = -16.67%. In transaction B he buys at Rs 8 each and sells at Rs 10 each and gains a profit of 2 ÷ 8 = +25%. That is the end of business story. Hence net gain is +25% - 16.67% = +8.33% on cost. Let us verify the statistics. Assuming the quantity of fruits bought and sold in each case is 1000 pcs: In one case principal is Rs 12000 and loss is 2000. In the 2nd case principal is Rs 8000 and profit is 2000. As the investment varies between the two cases, the profit / loss also varies as a per cent on investment in each case. Done.
Neither profit nor loss!! 12*10=₹120 8*10=₹80 (120+80)/20=₹10/piece So neither profit nor loss.
